Award.AwardTitle: The SEaRCH: Towards the Development of a STEM Education Research Consortium at HBCUs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities - Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) provides support to undertake an institutional self-analysis in preparation for a Broadening Participation Research Center. Broadening Participation Research Centers are expected to serve as national hubs for the rigorous study and broad dissemination of the critical pedagogies and culturally sensitive interventions that contribute to the success of HBCUs in educating African American STEM undergraduates. This project is a collaborative effort between the initial members of an education research consortium: Tennessee State University, Prairie View A&M University, Morgan State University, North Carolina A&T State University, and Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University. The consortium of schools and team of researchers will work to plan research activities that will lead to the formation of a research center that delineates which individual factors, environmental factors, institutional practices, procedures, and policies are most effective in ensuring that students successfully complete STEM degrees at HBCUs.

Activities of this project include: implementating a strategic planning framework built upon the broadening participation education research expertise of the collaborating institutions involved in the development of an expanded education research consortium of HBCUs; using evidence-based strategies to generate a high-quality plan for the research thrusts and research methodologies of the resulting center; and addressing the gap in the literature regarding STEM education research results, practices and policies pertinent to student persistence and graduation at HBCUs. The project will be guided by an on-going evaluation and an external advisory committee.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This planning project involved a consortium of universities and team of researchers who worked collectively to plan research activities for the formation of a research center to study factors that impact successful completion of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) undergraduate degrees. The selected research thrusts focused on four broad areas; 1) University policies and practices, 2) faculty attitudes and perceptions, 3) professional and gender identity, and 4) culture. Each of these areas provide opportunities for further study and the creation of programs to increase the number of students earning STEM degrees.

The project team also created a survey in order to better understand the perceptions and experiences of students and faculty in STEM disciplines at their universities; Tennessee State University, Prairie View A&M University, Morgan State University, and North Carolina A&T State University. The survey was completed by a total of 579 students and 69 faculty at the four HBCU partner institutions. The responses revealed that all institutions, both faculty and students indicated that inadequate high school preparation in STEM subjects and study skills negatively impact academic performance. The study also revealed that students lose confidence due to low grades in early STEM courses. This points to a need to improve preparation in high school and provide academic support as students transition to STEM majors in college.

Results of this research have been shared at engineering education conferences and will significantly contribute to increasing the persistence of STEM majors at Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs); thereby, contributing to the development of a diverse future STEM workforce.
